page.title: 10Transport.
page.content: The Railway. Riding Mill station is one of the oldest surviving passenger stations in the world. The line between Blaydon and Hexham was opened on 9th March 1835. Two steam locomotives left Blaydon, Stephenson's "Rapid" and Hawthorn's "Comet". The seventeen mile journey took two hours forty-five minutes, due to some problems but the return journey only took one hour and ten minutes. After that four regular passenger trains a day ran between Blaydon and Hexham. Today diesel trains run from Newcastle to Carlisle through Riding Mill. The journey to Riding Mill takes thirty-five minutes and costs Â£1.00. The old station master's house is now lived in by the school caretaker and the ticket office is an elderly person's flat.
